column4: Hi, I'm running ubuntu 10.10, and a few weeks ago I applied some updates, one of which I believe was a kernel update, since then my computer won't boot into Ubuntu, it stops on 'checking battery state...', I have an NVidia GForce 310M, and an i5 processor (so two graphics chips), I think I had the additional non-free grahics drivers Ubuntu pushed at me, how can I begin to fix the problem?
tried running the laptop on AC?
yes, it's plugged into the mains charger
remove the intel driver/s from apt-get
I'd love to, but I've not got past the 'Checking battery state...'
you need to edit some entries in grub, and add "init=/bin/bash"
do this: reboot the machine. in grub, press 'e' and then 'c', do what I told you, and then run linux (ctrl+x IIRC)
hmm remove either the free one (nouveau?) or the non-free (nvidia-something)
ubuntu shouldn't have this kind of problems
it depends on a lot of things... don't know about this particular case...
did it work?. perhaps the free drivers are interferring with the nonfree
just install either the free or the non-free, I think X shoud reconfigure itself
no need to reinstall, this is not windows :)
you can remove the config file, X will try to load the best config it can
